body:
### Describe the bug

Defining a `cfunc` or `ccall` method on an extension `cclass` with a name that's a reserved C++ keyword causes C++ compiler errors.

### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

**`cclass_collision.py`**
```cython
from __future__ import annotations
import cython

@cython.cclass
class SomeCls:
	@cython.cfunc
	def new(self) -> int:
		return 0
```

**BASH**
```Bash
$ cython -a --cplus cclass_collision.py -o cclass_collision.cpp &&
g++ -O0 -I /usr/include/python3.10 cclass_collision.cpp -o cclass_collision.so
```

**`g++` output**
```Bash
/lib/python3.10/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Main.py:345: FutureWarning: Cython directive 'language_level' not set, using '3str' for now (Py3). This has changed from earlier releases! File: /tmp/cclass_collision.py
  tree = Parsing.p_module(s, pxd, full_module_name)
cclass_collision.cpp:1291:15: error: expected unqualified-id before ‘new’
 1291 |   PyObject *(*new)(struct __pyx_obj_16cclass_collision_SomeCls *);
      |               ^~~
cclass_collision.cpp:1291:15: error: expected ‘)’ before ‘new’
 1291 |   PyObject *(*new)(struct __pyx_obj_16cclass_collision_SomeCls *);
      |             ~ ^~~
      |               )
cclass_collision.cpp: In function ‘int __Pyx_modinit_type_init_code()’:
cclass_collision.cpp:3527:43: error: expected unqualified-id before ‘new’
 3527 |   __pyx_vtable_16cclass_collision_SomeCls.new = (PyObject *(*)(struct __pyx_obj_16cclass_collision_SomeCls *))__pyx_f_16cclass_collision_7SomeCls_new;
      |                                           ^~~
```

### Expected behaviour

Probably mangle the name same as in any other case?

### Environment

OS: Linux
Python 3.10.7, 3.10.8
Cython 3.0.0a11


### Additional context

_No response_

comment_data.body:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/0c8dea13946833606ab7e290d51cd12aee077c04/Cython/Compiler/Symtab.py#L39 

We do specially mangle some names that definitely conflict with C keywords. We could guard C++ keywords too when in C++ mode.

title: [BUG] C++ reserved names aren't handled for `cclass` methods.
